topic.title: HPE Helion 1.2 Development Platform: Installation and Configuration

titlealts.searchtitle: HPE Helion 1.2 Development Platform: Commercial Installation and Configuration

body.p: HPE Helion Development Platform version 1.2 currently contains the Application Lifecycle Service, Database, Marketplace, and Messaging services.

The following topics explain how to install and configure a new deployment of the HPE Helion Development Platform version 1.2. There is also Troubleshooting documentation to handle issues that may occur.

li.xref: Downloading, Installing, and Updating the HPE Helion Development Platform

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: The HPE Helion Development Platform is installed in the overcloud of HPE Helion OpenStack(R)

Note: Helion OpenStack(R) version 1.1.1 is required for Helion Development Platform 1.2. Installing Helion Development Platform 1.2 on Helion OpenStack(R) versions 1.1 or 1.0 is not supported. If you currently have Helion OpenStack(R) version 1.1 with Helion Development Platform 1.1 installed, you will need to do the following to install Helion Development Platform 1.2:

ul.li: Perform a fresh install of Helion OpenStack(R) version 1.1.1
Install Helion Development Platform 1.2

section.p: Before you begin installation:

li.p: The Cinder block storage service must be configured with either VSA or 3Par.
If you installed HPE Helion OpenStack(R) with KVM hypervisor support, configure HPE StoreVirtual VSA for Block Storage or configure HPE 3PAR StoreServ Storage.

The system running the installer needs to have Python 2.7. Most modern operating systems include this as part of their base toolkit. This document is geared toward a Linux operating system but this does not preclude the installer from running on other operating systems with some minor modifications to the command-line statements.

The HPE Helion Development Platform installer (DevelopmentPlatform_Enable.sh) must be run on either the base or seed node of the Helion OpenStack(R) environment. It is strongly recommended to run the installer on the seed node. The seed node will already have the requisite key (/root/.ssh/id_rsa) for access to the overcloud; if the installation is run on the base node, this key will need to be provided to the installer (see below).
The installer requires the following packages. If they are not found, it will prompt you to install them.

ul.li: python-dev
libffi-dev
libssl-dev
python-virtualenv
python-pip

li.p: These packages can be installed using apt-get on the Base node, but on the Seed node, you 'll need to use pip to install the following packages:

li.codeph: pip install cffi enum34 pyasn1 virtualenv

section.title: Downloading, Installing, and Updating HPE Helion Development Platform
Downloading the Latest Version of HPE Helion Development Platform
section.p: The installation of the HPE Helion Development Platform for HPE Helion OpenStack(R) is provided as a small compressed tar file. The images for the actual services will be downloaded at the installer's request.
Note: Should you need more assistance during installation, the install script also has a help feature.

li.p: Register at and download the package from the HPE Helion Download Network (HDN). Verify that the package you download is 1.2.0.4 or later.
Before you begin the installation, unpack the tar file.

section.title: Installing the HPE Helion Development Platform

li.p: Navigate to the dev-platform-installer directory inside the dev-platform-installer.

If your network uses a proxy, it may be necessary to set the https_proxy shell variable so that the installer may download required Python libraries from the pypi site. To set the https_proxy shell variable, enter the following command:

codeblock.codeph: export https_proxy={ip address or url of http proxy}

li.p: Example:

Confirm that you have access to the pypi site. The following commands will verify access to the site and download one of the prerequisite files as a brief test. Note: If ping is unavailable, use wget.

codeblock.codeph: ping pypi.python.org sudo -E pip install python-novaclient

li.p: If your network uses a proxy, you must define the proxy exclusion list so that proxies are not used for communicating with the services in the overcloud. To define the proxy exclusion list, enter the following command:

codeblock.codeph: export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,{ip address or host name of identity service aka keystone}

li.p: Example:
Validate Keystone access on port 5000 using curl. Since Keystone access uses secure HTTP, you'll need to either use the certificate, or run curl with the --insecure switch to ignore SSL:

codeblock.codeph: # Use one or the other of the following two lines to verify connectivity: curl --cacert ephemeral-cacert.crt https://{ip address or host name of identity service aka keystone}:5000 # Use own CACert curl --insecure https://{ip address or host name of identity service aka keystone}:5000 # Ignore SSL

li.p: Example:

codeblock.codeph: # Use one or the other of the following two lines to verify connectivity: curl --cacert ephemeral-cacert.crt https://10.0.0.10:5000 # Use own CACert curl --insecure https://10.0.0.10:5000 # Ignore SSL

li.p: If you are installing from the Helion OpenStack(R) base node rather than the seed node, you will need to retrieve the CA certificate file from the overcloud controller. To do this, follow these steps:
Find the IP address for controller0:

codeblock.codeph: OVERCLOUD_CONTROLLER=$(ssh root@192.0.2.1 -C ' export TE_DATAFILE=~/tripleo/ce_env.json; source ~/tripleo/tripleo-incubator/undercloudrc; nova list |grep controller0 |cut -d= -f2 |cut -d" " -f1')

li.p: Copy the CA Certificate locally:

Run this command to install the Helion Development Platform. By default the Username is admin and the Region is regionOne. Use the admin tenant_id from the overcloud. The parameter location/ephemeralca-cacert.crt can be found on the seed at /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/ephemeralca-cacert.crt

Note: This installer will check to ensure that you are installing on a compatible version of Helion OpenStack(R) You will only be allowed to install Helion Development Platform if you meet a minimum Helion OpenStack(R) version requirement (1.1.1). If the version of Helion OpenStack(R) is not compatible, you will see the following error:

codeblock.codeph: You are attempting to install Helion Development Platform version 1.2 on Helion OpenStack(R) Build 81. Can not continue. Minimum required Helion OpenStack(R) build number for this install is 85.

li.p: If the version of Helion OpenStack(R) can't be determined, you will see the following error:

codeblock.codeph: Can not identify Helion OpenStack(R) version. Version information not found from /root/tripleo/images/overcloud-compute*.qcow2 Can not continue. Minimum required Helion OpenStack(R) build number for this install is 85.

section.title: Installing Services
section.p: The following steps describe how to download, install, and configure each of the Helion Development Platform services (Application Lifecycle Service [ALS], Messaging, Database, and Marketplace) using the Horizon interface.

section.title: Application Lifecycle Service (ALS)
section.p: The following section demonstrates how to perform the initial installation and configuration of ALS.

section.title: Step 1: Retrieve the ALS Service Update from HDN
Preparation
section.p: Be sure that the Admin project is checked from the Project selector before you check for service updates. The Project selector is located at the top of the page to the right of the OpenStack(R) logo. This process will fail if a tenant/project other than "Admin" is selected.

section.title: Retrieve the Update
section.p: Use the Helion Development Platform UI to check HDN for a new Service Update for ALS.
If there is a new Service Update for ALS, retrieve it from HDN. This will retrieve the ALS package from HDN and push it to a container in Swift within your local cloud.

section.title: Step 2: Configure the Service
section.p: Return to the Helion Development Platform UI and click Configure Services to configure the service.

section.title: Install the Messaging Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Messaging service from the Development Platform.

ol.li: Open Horizon and login as the "admin" user. You must run the entire install logged in as "admin".

li.p: Click on the Admin panel in Horizon and select Development Platform. Finally, click Configure Services.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services screen and enter your username and password for the HPE Download Network (HDN). Select the Sign-up button if you do not have an account.

section.title: Download and Configure the Messaging Service

li.p: In the Configure Services panel locate the Messaging item in the Configure Services table and select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.
Note: Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.
Once the download is complete, click the Configure Service button to configure the Messaging Service and wait for the configuration step to complete.

The installation is complete. Return to the Horizon dashboard (you may log out and log in with a non-Admin account if desired), and click on the Messaging panel under the current Project to begin using the Messaging Service.

section.title: Install the Database Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Database Service from the Development Platform.

section.title: Availability Zones
section.p: To configure the Database Service in a highly available manner, it is necessary to create separate availability zones. As a best practice, HPE recommends creating three availability zones. All compute hosts should be placed within one of these availability zones. If a compute host is not associated with an availability zone, the Database Service will not be able to provision a database instance to it. As a result, the Database Service may run out of capacity even though there are compute hosts with free capacity.
The following steps show how to create three availability zones and assign a compute host to the zone.

li.p: Connect to an overcloud controller node and execute the following commands to create three availability zones named: "AZ-1", "AZ-2" and "AZ-3".

codeblock.codeph: nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-1 AZ-1 nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-2 AZ-2 nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-3 AZ-3

section.title: Quotas
section.p: The Database Service will be installed into the admin tenant of the Helion OpenStack(R) overcloud and the admin tenant must have sufficient quota available and unused resources for the service to use. To check existing quota availability, log-in to Horizon as the admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.

In addition to the quota mentioned above, for every database instance that is created by a user, the necessary resources to create that instance will be deducted from the admin tenant quota. The users database service quota will also be affected.

ol.li: Open Horizon and login as the "admin" user. You must run the entire install logged in as "admin".

li.p: Click on the admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform panel under Admin. Then click on the Configure Services sub-panel.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services panel and enter your username and password for the HPE Download Network (HDN). Select the Sign-up button if you do not have an account.
In the Configure Services panel locate the Database Service item in the Configure Services table and select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.
Note: Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.

section.title: Configuring the Database Service

li.p: Once the download is complete, click the Configure Service button to begin configuration of the service. In the configuration dialog, specify the following configuration options:

ul.li: Service User Password (Required) - The password for the Admin user that is currently logged in. This password MUST match the password used to log in to Horizon.
Key Pair (Required) - Key Pair to install on all instances created as part of the database service. The public key can be used by an admin to get SSH access to all instances.
External Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has external network access. For HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Commercial Edition this network is named ext-net .
Provider Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has network access to cloud infrastructure services. For HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Commercial Edition this network is named SVC.
NTP Server IP - IP Address to an NTP server to use if instances will not have outbound access to the internet.
Logstash RabbitMQ IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Logstash RabbitMQ Password (Required) - Specify the password for the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Ephemeral CA Password (Required) - Specify the password for the Ephemeral CA server.
Ephemeral CA IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of Ephemeral CA server.
Volume Type (Required) - The volume type to use when creating database instances.

li.p: Enable HA - Specify if the database service is to be set up in a high-availability (HA) configuration. If selected, each component of the service will have three instances created and active at all times.
After all configuration options have been provided, select the Configure button to complete the configuration step. Wait for the configuration step to complete and the status to change to Configured.

section.title: Install the Marketplace Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Marketplace service from the Development Platform.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: The Marketplace Service will be installed into the admin tenant of the Helion OpenStack(R) overcloud and the admin tenant must have sufficient quota available and unused for the resources the service uses. To check existing quota availability, log-in to Horizon as the admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.

section.title: Installing the Marketplace Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Marketplace service from the Development Platform.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: The Marketplace Service will be installed into the admin tenant of the Helion OpenStack(R) overcloud. The admin tenant must have sufficient quota available and unused for the resources the service uses. To check existing quota availability, log in to Horizon as the admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.

section.title: Ports
section.p: If both the Marketplace and the Database Service are running on a single tenant, the default quota limit for Ports (50) is insufficient and the installation will not complete.

ol.li: Open Horizon and login as the "admin" user. You must run the entire install logged in as "admin".

li.p: Click on the admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform Panel under Admin. Then click on the Configure Services sub-panel.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services panel and enter your username and password for the HPE Download Network (HDN). Select the Sign-up button if you do not have an account.
In the Configure Services panel, in the Configure Services table, locate the Marketplace Service item. Select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.
Note: Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.

section.title: Configuring the Marketplace Service

li.p: Once the download is complete, click the Configure Service button to begin configuration of the service. In the configuration dialog, specify the following configuration options:

ul.li: Service User Password (Required) - The password for the Admin user that is currently logged in. This password MUST match the password used to log in to Horizon.
Key Pair (Required) - Key Pair to install on all instances created as part of the database service. The public key can be used by an admin to get SSH access to all instances.
External Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has external network access. For HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Commercial Edition this network is named 'ext-net'
Provider Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has network access to cloud infrastructure services. For HPE Helion OpenStack(R) Commercial Edition this network is named 'SVC'
NTP Server IP - IP Address to an NTP server to use if instances will not have outbound access to the internet.
Logstash RabbitMQ IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Logstash RabbitMQ Password (Required) - Specify the password for the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Ephemeral CA Password (Required) - Specify the password for the Ephemeral CA server.
Ephemeral CA IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of Ephemeral CA server.
Subnet range (Required) - The subnet to use for Marketplace.

li.p: Do not attempt to install any Marketplace packages yet. Log out from the Horizon console.

Open the /etc/haproxy/manual/paas.cfg file and add the following lines. Note: The last line should be repeated once for each API server identified in step 1.

codeblock.codeph: listen marketplace_api bind <Virtual IP from step 2>:8082 option httpchk GET / server marketplace<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 check-ssl ca-file /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt

Download the Vertica package.
a) Open Horizon and log in as the "admin" user. Then click on the admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform Panel under Admin. Then click on the Configure Services sub-panel.
b) Select the "Vertica Trial Package for Marketplace".
c) Select Download Service, and confirm the download.

section.p: Your installation is now complete. If you encounter problems, refer to the Troubleshooting documentation.
